description: From Middle English loken, lokien, from Old English lōcian, from Proto-West Germanic *lōkōn. Further origin unknown, no certain cognates outside Germanic. The English word, however, is cognate with Scots luke, luik, leuk (“to look, see”), West Frisian lôkje, loaitsje (“to look”), Dutch loeken (“to look”), German Low German löken, Alemannic German luege (“to look”), German lugen (“to look”), Yiddish לוגן‎ (lugn). Possibly related to Sanskrit लोक् (lok, “to see, behold”) (from Proto-Indo-European *lewk- (“light”) in the sense of "illuminating" (cf. related word रुच् (ruc) "to shine, illuminate")).

entries.meaning: The action of looking; an attempt to see.
examples: Let’s have a look under the hood of the car.
She got her mother’s looks.
I don’t like the look of the new design.
He gave me a dirty look.
If looks could kill ...

verbs.description: look (third-person singular simple present looks, present participle looking, simple past and past participle looked)

definitionGroups.group: To try to see, to pay attention to with one’s eyes.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) As an intransitive verb, often with "at".
examples: Troponyms: glance; see also Thesaurus:stare
They kept looking at me.
Don’t look in the closet.

entries.meaning: (transitive, colloquial) As a transitive verb, often in the imperative; chiefly takes relative clause as direct object.
examples: Look what you did to him!
Look who's back!
It looks as if it’s going to rain soon.
Our new boss looks to be a lot more friendly.

entries.meaning: (copulative) To give an appearance of being.
examples: That painting looks nice.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, often with "for") To search for, to try to find.
To face or present a view.
examples: The hotel looks over the valleys of the HinduKush.
I look to each hour for my lover’s arrival.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To express or manifest by a look.
examples: Soft eyes looked love to eyes which spake again,

entries.meaning: (transitive, often with "to") To make sure of, to see to.
examples: "Look to it yourself, father," answered Telemachus, "for they say you are the wisest counsellor in the world, and that there is no other mortal man who can compare with you. […]

entries.meaning: (dated, sometimes figurative) To show oneself in looking.
examples: Look out of the window [i.e. lean out] while I speak to you.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To look at; to turn the eyes toward.
(transitive, obsolete) To seek; to search for.
examples: Looking my love, I go from place to place,  Like a young fawn that late hath lost the hind;  And seek each where, where last I saw her face,  Whose image yet I carry fresh in mind.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To influence, overawe, or subdue by looks or presence.
examples: to look down opposition

entries.meaning: (baseball) To look at a pitch as a batter without swinging at it.
examples: The fastball caught him looking.
Clem Labine struck Mays out looking at his last at bat.
It's unusual for Mays to strike out looking. He usually takes a cut at it.
